description.text: Bike pedal to replace the broken stock one. Instead of spending 20 bucks to buy a pair from walmart, I decided to design and print one myself. First one printed in PLA with 40% honeycomb infill, snapped in half after about 2 months of daily commute due to cold weather. Second one printed in taulman 910 nylon with 35% honeycomb infill, incredibly strong and is working well. Should fit on all 1/2 inch thread Kent KZR pedals.

author: ryks

description.text:
This is a jig to allow you to square your model rocket's fins when you are gluing them. This jig fits a MadCow Arcas HV (2.6" diameter)  but could be resized fairly easy for other rockets.
Extra feature: Rail guide. Basically, you want the rail guide to be as straight as humanly possible. This can be done with a lot of measuring, or by turning this jig on its side and (assuming your laser cutter can do straight lines) used as a jig for the rail guides.

Cut two or more on 5mm acrylic or plywood. Keep triangles handy
To center the fins: with rocket vertical, add fins with epoxy and use a third hand to hold them in place, while you fit the jig over them. add epoxy over edges to create fillets. There is a rounded edge on the jig so that you can use the jig to clean and round the fillets while the epoxy sets
To center the rail guide: assemble the standing trinagles and run the rocket through the middle of the jig, with one ijg fit to the fins and the other where you want to mark the rail guide. Mark the rail guides using the square divet in the jig on each end. I'll have pictures shortly.

The circuit board in these units can be removed easily and placed into the one I designed (the green plastic wire connector has two small prongs on it which need to be pulled up to unplug it from the main board and then slipped through the hole on the side. title: The Rion Antirion Bridge Replica (1:1000), MFR

description.text:
These are the files of my project for the Maker Faire Rome (Call for Makers).

It is a 1:1000 Replica of the Rion Antirion Bridge in Greece. It is meant to show how 3D Printing can be used in Engineering, especially Civil Engineering, to create replicas and models that allow the teacher to explain the design principles that make a structure earthquake- and windproof.

The instructions to print all of this and glue it all together are too much to write, so if someone is genuinely interrested in making the bridge themselves, let me know in the comments.

The water under the bridge is made of soap, all of the bridge was spray-painted, and and I used lead-tape to give the bridge the blue lighting.

It will take a lot of time and a lot of glue, so be prepared.

Note that there is no other 3D Design on the internet, and there are literally no true sketches on the internet that contain dimentions. As such, the designs are as close as they can be to real life. The one noticeable problem is that all of the pylons are a bit taller than normal, but it is not so noticeable.

The majority of the parts do not need supports, but some do, but they are very easy to remove. Add supports if you believe your printer needs them.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200-300 microns

Infill:

Varying (25-50)

Notes:

Ideally, use yellow filament for the bridge-under parts and white plastic for the rest. The whites are to be painted over. I myself used PLA, with no issues (apart form some wrapping on some corners, and some underextrusion that was teh machine's fault).

Post Printing

Paint all of the parts for maximum realism. Much glue will be needed to complete the bridge. As a tip, if you glue two parts and they disconnect from each other, first trim the two glued surfaces with sandpaper or a dremel, and then reglue. Burned glue is toxic so beware.

Design Process

All of the models were made in SolidWorks 2015 and are uploaded on grabcad.com

https://grabcad.com/library/the-rion-antirion-bridge-replica-1-1000-mfr-1

Bill of materials:

Update 15.02.2017:
Added hex body for M8 nuts. The hex_cap is the same for both versions.

Please note that I have made them with exact dimensions measured on nut and bearing. If you have problems inserting the bearing and nuts, you can always upscale or downscale the model a bit in your slicer in order to make it fit

Added hex body and cap for "strange" nut by request.
Dimensions for nut: 14mm wrench, 8.22 thick
Dimensions for bearing: D=18.99mm; d=6mm; 5.98 thick
Note:

description.text: Stamp for etc.....

Just a quick LED mount I made for my kreigerpus so my race buddies can see how far in front it is (hehe). It was designed around Matek 4S RGB LED Circle (http://www.hobbyrc.co.uk/matek-4s-rgb-led-circle) but should work with just about anything you want to stick to it. (I used superglue)

The mount attaches onto the rear standoff on the pod, print in something flexible so that you can get the standoff through the hole, at an infill of 50% ish.

Alternatively scale the part up .2 to print in PLA or ABS and secure to the standoff with a blob of glue.

I'm happy to remix if someone wants a different shape, just leave a comment.

This is a knob for my 503HTA Hybrid tube amp, from Pi2 design; http://www.pi2design.com/store/p13/503HTA_-_Hybrid_Tube_Amp.html

As wide a knob as reasonably fits on the amp without blocking the adjacent attenuation switch.

A full 20mm of depth gives your fingers lots of easy to grip surface. Large flat corresponds to the knob flat to visually indicate volume level.

UPDATE: I've added a version 2 of the knob. This is the same basic design, with more knurls on the outside, and some of the edges rounded off.

UPDATE2: more of a comment. In the actual photo of the knob, this is with a PI2 and USB WiFi adapter. When the WiFi antenna is in the position shown it interferes with the audio. Rotating the antenna away from the system removed this interference.

title: 5°-30° Cam Mounts Vortex Pro 250 (Yi USB compatible)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted to use my Vortex Pro for movie purposes and therefore needed another angle than the 30° mount it comes with. It is precisely fitted for the slots of the original camera mount.

As I use the Xiaomi Yi I wanted to use the onboard voltage regulator of the Vortex to power the Yi while flying. This way I can leave it on the whole time flying, waiting for the next start and while changing batteries. If you use a standard micro-USB cable it should work fine and will center the camera.

These models where made in Inventor Pro 2015. If you want to modify the files, let me know.

title: Salzstreuer - Salt shaker - REMIX of salt and pepper shaker from Marcolara2580

description.text:
I have remixed (remodeled) this because I have printed the original with a 0.6 nozzle and the wall behind the text was too thin.

Simplify3D did not even wanted to slice it water tight. With cura it sliced OK but it did not went well.

So, here it is.

title: Dell BH200 headphone earpad retainer ring

description.text: The Dell BH200 uses a plastic retainer ring to snap the earpad cushion on to the main body of the headphones. After a few years, these break, causing the earpads to constantly fall off. This is a replacement retainer ring, which fits into the earpad. Replacement earpads are available from China on the popular online auction site.

print_settings.Notes:: .3 mm nozzle, PCTPE Nylon, hot end 244 deg. C, bed 100 deg. C, cooling fan off.  The setup is not critical I used the .3 mm nozzle because it was already on the printer

description.text:
This is an FPV camera mount for cameras of the RMRC-PRO700 form factor (ReadyMade RC). It fits the Vortex 285 quadcopter and replaces the front frame standoffs. Installation requires notching the top cover of the Vortex since the opening is narrower than the camera. Also the standoffs are replaced by 1.25 inch long #6 Nylon screws, ty-wraps can be used in lieu of screws.

This thing allows the FPV camera to be mounted between the top and bottom frame covers of the Vortex and frees up the clean frame for a camera such as a Mobius.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%

Notes:

.3 mm nozzle, PCTPE Nylon, hot end 244 deg. C, bed 100 deg. C, cooling fan off. The setup is not critical I used the .3 mm nozzle because it was already on the printer
Designed with Fusion 360 and sliced with Cura.

description.text:
UPDATE: I've added a new version (v4) which increases the overall thickness so I no longer need to use a nylon washer as a spacer and also removes the 2-3mm gap between the flag and mailbox.

We've been in our home for over six years now, and the flag on our mailbox was looking pretty tired. So, I designed several models and decided to print and uploaded version 3. I'm going to go back into Solidworks and increase the height of the "sidewalls" by another 2.5mm to make it match the original more closely. I'm also going to lengthen the shaft for the attaching screw as I needed to use a 2mm thick washer with version three.

I printed this with ABS at .3mm layer height and 15% infill. I also used a ten outline skirt in Simplified3D to help control warping.

title: Cracked! (Plato's Egg) puzzle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is my entry for the 2015 IPP Puzzle Design competition
http://www.johnrausch.com/DesignCompetition/2015/default.htm#08
Read more about the story behind this puzzle in the 'How I Designed This' section

The puzzle is composed of three nested layers of dodecahedra.
The challenge is to crack Plato's egg into its constituent parts, find and disassemble the trisected dodecahedron at the centre, then put it back together again.
Each of the three stages requires a degree of coordinate motion.
The white of the egg is particularly hard to disassemble by hand but will easily come apart by spinning the egg on the table.

You will need to print:
3 of the Shell pieces in light brown
2 of the White A pieces in white or clear
2 of the White B pieces in white or clear
3 of the Yolk pieces in yellow

If you like this puzzle, please consider leaving a tip to encourage me to share more of my puzzles.

Printer:

Mendel90

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15 to 0.2 mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

This is a tricky print that needs a well-tuned printer.
If your printer is over-extruding, the pieces will NOT fit together.
No support material should be required for any of the pieces but you will certainly need a good part cooling fan.

The idea for this puzzle came from asking one simple question: Can the surface of a dodecahedron all be subdivided into a number of identical interlocking parts?
Because the dodecahedron has 12 faces, there are four possible ways to divide these into equal groups. I soon discovered that two pieces each having a chain of six pentagonal faces would interlock but be impossible to separate. I also decided that six pieces each having two pentagonal faces would not make an interlocking puzzle. So, I began experimenting with three chains of four pentagons and discovered that it was indeed possible to wrap three identical shapes onto the surface of the dodecahedron. But would the pieces come apart? I used a computer program to extrude the shape outwards from a central point, turning it into a solid object. I printed out three of these shapes and proved that they could be assembled into a dodecahedron using a coordinate sliding motion.
I then tried by experimenting with four chains of three pentagons. It was fairly obvious that the four parts could be assembled into a dodecahedron quite easily but without interlocking, so they would not hold together. I then had the idea of combining two complete sets of these shapes, nested one inside the other. The three pentagons of the inner group were offset in relation to the three pentagons of the outer group which allowed the shapes to lock together. I created several designs that interlocked to form a complete dodecahedron but they were all impossible to solve. At the sixth attempt, I finally managed to print a set of four pieces that could actually be assembled into a dodecahedron with a coordinate sliding motion.
The final creative step came when I had the idea of combining the puzzles into a nested set of shapes representing the yolk, white and shell of an egg.
Can you crack Plato’s egg and put it back together?

title: Adjustable Cooling Nozzle for PLA or ABS/PETG- WIP

description.text:
This is a super rough draft version of an idea I had.

The original version of this nozzle has served me well for printing PLA, but for PETG, I needed to block the cooling on the bed. Instead of printing a new nozzle for that purpose or taping over it, I figured, why not make it adjustable.

It uses a cylinder across the nozzle with a slot in it. Turned one way, the airflow comes out for printing PLA. Turn it 90 degrees and it blocks the airflow for ABS or PETG.

I have not tested it and this is a first draft. I am hoping to clean it up and need to fix the nozzle a bit, but in theory, it would work as-is.

It is set up to print in one piece, with no supports.

If you are good with 3d design and want to run with the idea, PLEASE DO! I am sure anyone of you talented people can do better than I did. I just wanted to get the idea out there.

Monoprice MP Select Mini

title: FlashForge Creator Pro Improved Fan Shroud (2016 model)

description.text: This is an improved version of the fan shroud that is currently shipping with the 2016 model Flash Forge Creator Pros. I kept it focused on a single hot end rather then both as I have no desire to make dual-extrusion prints and keep the second hot end for ABS only. This shroud directs the air all around the nozzle rather then just the left side, resulting in much better part cooling with PLA and PETG. It prints great out of ABS and is far enough away from the nozzle/heater block to not heat up and warp during longer prints. This mounts directly into the existing cooling fan and uses the same screw holds.

Flash Forge Creator Pro

This is an acquisition radar for the Matchbox MXT toy tuck. The file is just the parts for the radar (truck not included). However, they be found with a little luck wherever toys are sold.
This protect is part of an attempt to make support vehicles for the A.M.V.P.'s. To offset the cost of the fully printed AMVP's, I wanted to keep this project as inexpensive as possible, so utilizing the toy trucks was key. The trucks can be found for about a dollar and there is about $4 worth of printing, but that will of coarse very. I used filament to attach the radar parts, this also allows the radar to move, as well as to fold down. Hope you enjoy!

description.text:
I broke mine, so I made this! It's a replacement antenna cover for a Spektrum DX9 Radio.

Normally, the antenna cap mounts with 2 screws and 3 plastic hooks. If you shear off the hooks from opening the case too many times, it will become unstable. I used a combination of precise measurements and photocopied base profiles to formulate the shape…

After about 10 prototypes I've perfected the fit! It doesn't wobble, and is about as strong as it can realistically be without adding excess material. This cap is also shorter than the original, making it a bit more convenient.

description.text: This bridge was completely designed using research. It is a testable bridge what uses an arch and cables for strength. Use 1.75mm filament for the cables and print on its side. Instructions in below sections. I ADVISE USING PLA DUE TO ABS LAYER ADHESION ISSUES!!!!!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1 or 0.2

Infill:

50

Notes:

Print on side (on one of the arches). One side is not perfectly level and so (depending on slicer) wont print with first layer no matter how it is oreanted. This didn't cause any problems for me though. I will fix this soon.

Step 1

remove from printer and slide 1.75mm filament through a hole in an arch. Slide through corresponding hole in road. Cut to size leaving a small amount of extra filament on both sides. Do this for all holes and after each one, secure in place by melting the extra to the bridge ( I used a soildering iron).

comments.text: I'd suggest going back and looking at early bridge designs. If you're new to civil engineering its worth researching trusses, you'll find they're fairly easy to design, print and strong.

title: Gun turret for Matchbox MXT toy truck.

description.text: This is a gun turret for the Matchbox MXT toy tuck. These files are just the parts for the gun, turret, and base, (truck not included). However, they be found with a little luck wherever toys are sold. This protect is part of an attempt to make support vehicles for the A.M.V.P.'s. To offset the cost of the fully printed AMVP's, I wanted to keep this project as inexpensive as possible, so utilizing the toy trucks was key. The trucks can be found for about a dollar and there is about $4 worth of printing, but that will of coarse very. I used filament to attach the turret to the base which allows it to rotate, the gun can also elevate up and down. Hope you enjoy!

comments.author: jimbo74

comments.text: Hey, i dont know if u are aware but you need to "slice" the STL file (what you get in here) in order to print it. The "slicer" is a program (there are some free neat ones such as cura, slic3r or repetier) that disects the STL file into a "g code" (a list of commands). that your printer follows. So a printer will not recognize an STL, you need a g code for it to work

description.text:

I want you to know that I create these designs to encourage people to try out flexible filaments or get some new interesting colors of flexibles. For info on purchasing samples of 6 different types of flexible filament see flexyfilament.com

comments.text: Feel free to spend the time making a bunch of holes in your CAD program. Drilling was much faster for me.
comments.author: dmwahl

comments.text: Most CAD software will let you create a pattern, create one hole and then it will duplicate them however you specify. I wasn't trying to be a jerk, just asking if there was some reason you chose to drill them later rather than modeling them in. I'd be worried about leaving shavings from the drill bit inside.
comments.author: cwhites108

comments.text: Lol, no offense taken at all.  Like I said, for me, drilling was faster. I wasn't or am concerned about shavings. The file is there for you to use. Use it as you see fit amigo.

title: bearing supported spool cradle with filament guide (fits Wanhao i3 built-in bolt holes)

description.text:
This is a ball bearing supported filament spool holder that is compact, can mount using the Wanhao i3 frame spool bolt holes, and has a built-in filament guide. The filament guide is a captive ball joint that will fit 4mm diameter teflon tubing. I haven't yet developed a good solution for capturing the bottom end of the filament guide tube at the extruder, so for now I'm using a short length of teflon tube held only at the guide end in order to keep control of the filament as it leaves the spool.

My priorities for this cradle design were compactness, ball bearings for very low friction and force required to pull filament off the spool, and to keep control of the filament and provide just enough friction in the filament guide to keep the filament spools from turning too much on the ball bearings as filament unwinds.

The filament cradle is printed out as a single piece.

The spindle is designed to accept two end caps (I refer to them as bobbins) with appropriate spacers to ensure that the end caps are centered on the spindle. I designed this originally for my Monoprice 1kg spools, and the end caps fit the Monoprice spool bore. With the Monoprice inner spacers, the Monoprice end caps, and the spindle, the end caps touch the inner ring of the skateboard-style (VXB 608 ZZ) ball bearings to keep the spool centered and trapped on the spindle.

I've designed inner and outer spacers, and an end cap, that will allow Hatchbox 1kg spools to be mounted on this. I'm currently printing these out to test them, and will add them to this project as soon as I know the dimensions are correct.

I invite others to work out parameterized versions of the end cap, the spacers, etc. to allow people to easily fit other brand spools on this cradle. To make this easier I've attached my SolidWorks source files for these parts. I'm brand new to SolidWorks, and this is my first SolidWorks project, so I acknowledge that the way I did these is probably not optimal.

Also, if someone has any good ideas to make a better spindle/end cap combo design to make this more extensible, more simple, or whatever, please feel free to do it and link it back to this cradle project. I'm brand new to designing things, so I know there's got to be much cleverer ways to do this, and I'd love to see it happen.

EDIT 13 November 2016: I just added STL files for inner spacers and end caps that fit the eSun 1kg spool and the Hatchbox 1kg spool. This cradle now contains everything necessary to support Monoprice, eSun, and Hatchbox 1kg spools. As I pick up new brands with different spool widths and bores I'll make end caps and inner spacers to mount them on my cradle, and I'll add them to the project. These are easy to design, though, for any arbitrary spool that will at least fit within this framework, which should be most spools.

comments.text: I don't see the STL file for the Cradle... Am I missing something?
comments.author: drbogger

comments.text: It's called "full_spool_holder_assembly.STL". I have to apologize in a way for the mess of different parts, some of them with file sizes much larger than they need to be, etc. This was one of my first designs. I did it in SolidWorks, and the two end pieces were different parts from the base plate, and the triangular part with the ball joint was also a separate part. They were joined together into a single SolidWorks "assembly," and so I released it with that name.
comments.author: drbogger

comments.text: Yeah, my design does require specific spool end caps and for some of them, some spacers. I've currently got three brands of spools attached as files, and have been using this for several months. The three spool types I've supported so far are Monoprice 1kg spools, Hatchbox 1kg spools, and eSun 1kg spools.

title: 5" touchscreen Raspberrryry PI LCD Bezil with Taz 3 control box cover

description.text: This is a set of mounting hinges, LCD container boxes, and associated bracketry for installing a 5 inch HDMI touchscreen for Raspberry Pi in the dead space in front of the Lulabot Taz 3 (or 4/5 with a bit of modificiation) control box. This will allow you to make your printer look cooler, and be more functional at the same time, which is a win! This uses several M3 heat set inserts, 2 M3 10mm bolts, 10 M3 6mm bolts, 4 M3 12 or 14mm bolts, a really long ribbon cable (26 pin, prefferably mail one end and female the other, though those seem to be very rare) and ribbon hdmi calbe for Raspbery Pi .

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.5mm

Infill:

85% or better

Notes:

Printed with ABS, PLA or other plastics would work well. Support is already integrated into the model.

Instructions.

Print out the things. Install 8 M3 heat set inserts in the front LCD bezil, 2 in the rear box cover, 2 in whichever LCD bracket hinge thing gets them installed in the ends, and 2 n the Taz 3 control box cover (or adapt this to fit on anyother control box - If there is interest I'll make a 4/5 specific variant that will fit. )

Then bolt everything together, feed the wires through where they need to go, and you should be all set. I'm not listing a wire source at this time, because I am looking for better variants of both wires.

title: Press On NEMA 14 Motor Fan
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Press On NEMA 14 Motor Fan Intro

I recently bought my first 3D printer via Craigslist--a Solidoodle 2 Pro. It's a cute little printer but the Devil is in the details and many stock features essentially need upgrading or workarounds. In this instance, my stock Solidoodle 2 X-axis motor was so hot to the touch that it startled me--it had neither a heat sink nor fan. The Y and Z axis motors wick away heat because they're bolted directly to enclosures metal frame.

My first fix was to super glue a box fan onto a generic part printed from Thingiverse. The fan was about twice the sizeof the motor. I wanted something smaller. I had an old ATI graphics card laying around with a 12V Sunon 125010VX-A ATI graphics card fan and having just completed the Instructables 3D printing course with Fusion 360 decided to apply my newly learned skills to designing a part around the fan and the motor.

Print this thing and screw in the fan with logo side facing out (see photos). Press fit onto NEMA 14 motor to provide constant cooling for the Solidoodle 2 Pro X-axis motor. I soldered headers onto my stock Sanguinololu board for 12V and GND. It might also be possible to splice into the extruder fan wire to provide power. The motor now is cool to the touch even during 10+ hour prints.

References

  • https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Free-Shipping-For-SUNON-125010VX-A-12V-2-3W-ATI-graphics-card-fan/853303388.html
  • 1.8° Nema 14, Size 35mm High Torque Hybrid Stepping Motor
    http://www.smartautomation.com.cn/ProductShow.asp?ArticleID=500
  • Good photos of the PCB where you'll connect 12V DC fan to power http://blog.rona.fr/post/2014/09/14/Adding-a-fan-to-a-Sanguinololu-v1.2

I've also imported the STL from Fusion 360 into SketchUp and played around with it and all seems well no bugs in the solid. Tolerances allow press on fit with my printer. You might print a few layers and kill the print and test fit.

description.text: I needed a Spare key but wasn't able to have one made. This is a Y11 key blank, (different manufacturers may call it by a different name) This is a VERY popular key blank style used by Yale and many other manufacturers. This key can be used in cam locks, golf cart type ignitions, mailboxes, locking gas/petrol caps, Tool boxes, etc. etc. etc. Though the picture of the actual print shows cuts in the key, this THING does not have them. Also, I verified the functionality and accuracy in MY lock, the tolerances of YOUR lock may vary and the key may not fit your lock's profile. I do not think this blank is good enough to be cut on a professional key cutting machine. I used SketchUp to add in my own "cuts" by simply printing the cuts into the key blank. Though this key DID work in my lock, it is fragile. Do not break the key off in your lock. Here is a Y13 Blank http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1871819

title: ShapeShifter Vase

description.text:
I ran across http://shapeshifter.io/, which makes it super easy to design 3D printable items like vases, & bowls, etc. I thought I'd try my hand at it, this was the first item I came up with: Simple vase.
No, I'm not a spokesman for them, but I thought others may find the site a good resource as well ;)

Printed successfully on a Replicator(1), glass built platform with hairspray. Used MakerWare's 'medium' settings, modified:
  • HBP : off
  • Extruder Temp : 220
  • Material : Natural PLA
  • Infill : 10%
  • Shells : 2
  • No raft, no support.
    Total time : 17h, 15min : Surprising it took this long, but there was a lot of starting & stopping with all the fine detail.
    Total weight: 165g
    • If you want to modify this vase design, here is a direct link to the ShapeShifter page with its settings: http://goo.gl/oZcwRV

description.text:

description.text:
This is my design for a 3-D printable assistive technology device which allows people with missing digits, reduced digital dexterity, flexibility or grip strength to carry nearly any type of hand held bag. For example, your grocery bags, a gym bag, or a briefcase.

UPDATE (10 Feb 2017) -
I was finally able to upload the improved model which allows a user to collapse the bag holder upon itself for compact storage and increased utility.

Special Note: The models should be printed in such a way as to have the planes of the printed layers parallel to the normal direction of loading (ie. downward). Printing the models with the planes of the printed layers orthogonal to the normal direction of loading may cause the printed parts to be ripped apart between the layers.

To use:

  1. Unfold the collapsed bag holder
  2. Insert the narrow width of your wrist into the top handle labelled "PART 1"
  3. Turn your wrist to secure the bag holder on your wrist, preventing it from slipping off.
  4. Position the handle(s) of the bag(s) you want to carry in the middle of the lower jaw labelled "PART 3". Positioning the handle(s) of your bag(s) in the middle of the lower jaw will help to evenly distribute the weight of the bag(s) for a more comfortable experience.

Future modifications:

  • Apply a fillet to the underside of the top handle. This will make the handle more comfortable when in contact with a person's wrist.
  • Reduce the dimension of the entire system to make it more compact while still being able to carry a moderate to heavy load.

If you are interested in more advanced open-source assistive technologies come check out the work our team is doing at MakersMakingChange.com and the Neil Squire Society

description.text:
I wanted a ninja-star spinner that still had the counter-weight of 3 bearings. The normal spinner is pretty large and requires big hands to spin (11 cm diameter). The smaller spinner is much more compact and is suitable for anyone (including children).

Standard 608 (22mm Diameter, 7mm height) bearings will pressure-fit, and caps can be printed from other projects (The caps from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1798896 are great!)

To get rounded edges, I ran a minkowski addition to a flat-ish area the shape of the spinner. This takes a LOOONG time in OpenSCAD at high settings, so be warned (or comment out the minkowski util you're absolutely ready, if you want to re-generate the STL).

title: Drylin Style Bushing RJ4JP-01-08 RJ4JP-01-10 (LM8UU and LM10UU direct replacement)

description.text:
Original version is the exact same thing that you can download from IGUS website. I just enlarged the center hole for PLA printing. It should fit perfectly on a 8mm rod, at least for my MK2.

V2 is the modify version from the original, I read somewhere on the internet that said this pattern works better than the original. I cannot really confirm that or back this up. But if you are interested in trying it or test it, you can download this version.

I do not actually design this bushing, all credit goes to IGUS or whoever design it. Again, Happy Printing.

UPDATE:
Upload the 10mm version since someone ask for it.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200, 100 microns

Notes:

Design to print in PLA because it seems to work the best compare to other filaments. Print best with 3 perimeters and at least 10% infill. Layer height does not matter.

comments.text:
He impreso en PLA, el archivo esta bastante bien diseñado, la cuestión es que hay que aumentar sus dimensiones 0,5 mm en cualquiera de sus ejes x ó y, para que quede perfectamente acoplado en la varilla de 8 mm, también hay que reducir el bloque donde va alojado dicho buje en aproximadamente 1,0 mm en el eje x o z.
A ver, es probable que el PLA no sea el material mas adecuado para hacer este diseño, la fricción que ejerce una maquina, como por ejemplo la Anet 8, que tiene dimensiones relativamente pequeñas, haya calentamiento en estos bujes, ya que el movimiento es lineal y el calentamiento posiblemente suceda en verano, como es mi caso, que se alcanzan temperaturas de mas de 40 grados centígrados, pero ahora en invierno, el calentamiento es mínimo, además esta contrastado con otros usuarios que han utilizado PLA para fabricarlos y el resultado es mas que satisfactorio.
Muchas gracias por compartir este diseño.
comments.author: Anetocho

comments.text:
A waste of time, PLA is not suitable for this purpose !
Your V2 version is just a bit elastic and therefore compensates for the incorrect sizes, avoiding binding.
Surface finish is unsuitable too. Will wear out quickly leading to excessive play.
The proper way is to use the proper material for ex. Igus filament, eventually Nylon, have the hole undersized and ream it to get the right surface finish and size.
And if you go with Igus filament, you can make the bearing smaller and easier to integrate in parts like carriage. Reduce size and weight.
In short, this is a bad copy of the Igus stl files. Will be worse than the Chinese SC8UU or bronze bushings.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: FDM 3D printing is all about waste of time.  None of the filament is suitable for such bushing unless you mold the plastic because it gives you a smooth surface.  Therefore, IGUS filament is a waste of money as well.  Just buy the bushings from them instead of printing it.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
I use Igus filament and it works very well. As I said, just a matter to finish them PROPERLY by using a reamer for example. The surface quality is quite good and provided you get a tight fit, you can "burnish" the surface with the smooth rod.
I did my own because it was a funny waste of time that turned out to be useful. I can make them in the size and shape I want (round, flat, V, lead screw nut ...) and integrate them in the parts which can be smaller, lighter.

title: Tevo Tarantula i3, Sides and Legs for Acrylic Display Case

description.text:
This is a side panel cover and legs for the Acrylic display on the Tevo Tarantula and other similar i3 Printers.

The long sides are split in two pieces as my Tevo was being rebuilt when I designed this.
So these were made on my Monoprice Mini Select.

They are designed to slip over the brass standoffs, and will use all factory hardware with the exception of : 2 M3x16 cap screws and 2 M3 nuts for the split long sides .
: 4 M3x20 cap screws washers and nuts for bolting the legs to the back case.
As a precaution, I placed a strip of electrical tape over the portion of pcb board for the lcd. This is to prevent the M3 screw in the split joint from scratching any traces. You will see what I mean, and see how I recessed the area of the sides for this.

THIS IS STILL A WORK IN PROGRESS. If anyone would like to contribute a 1 piece design of the long side, it would be more than welcome and I could provide the files if needed to do so. I am ok with where this turned out for me, so I don't plan on putting anymore time into it as of now....

Printer:

MonoPrice Select Mini

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Make sure to rotate object so long side is flat on the bed. Should print without support no problem. I rotated them all so the outsides were flat on the bed for a smooth finish.

Print 1 each of "SD CARD" and CABLE HOLE"
Print 2 each of "Long Side A" , "Long Side B" , and "Display legs"

author: hodginsa

title: Special Triangles
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: These are special triangles that I designed for spatial composition and decomposition exercises. These are appropriate for early grades, but are designed for middle-upper elementary as students are shifting from noticing features to properties. PDF files have frames for composing. The larger square frames are slightly larger than intended. I'll post a fix when I get around to it.
CCSS

Spatial Composition and Decomposition My colleagues and I published the pictured volume last year with Routledge. Here is a teacher review of the book: http://cohort21.com/rutheichholtz/2016/06/02/do-you-see-math/ Also, see my academic page for many resources: https://ucsb.academia.edu/DavidHallowell My work is built on the excellent work of Professor Douglas Clements' investigations of shape composition and decomposition activities. Here is an overview of the developmental trajectory

The PDF files contain frames that the children are asked to fill completely. Less experienced children will leave gaps, cross the frame boundary, etc.They need to be encouraged to completely fill the frame with no gaps or boundary crossing. A discussion of strategies helpful once children have had time to do the activity for a bit. Do they try the basics? Flips, rotations, reflections, etc. Do they use side lengths? What about angles (most advanced)? Once they get the basic (leftmost, small frame), do they visualize how to iterate to fill a larger frame? Can they predict how many shapes they'll need to fill the larger shape? How so?

3D printer, filament, paper, laminator. I use ColorFabb nGen on a Lulzbot 5. I've gotten really nice orthogonal edges by calibrating the bed and using a modified version of the recommended nGen profile, which I slowed down a bit. I recommend using a different color filament for each separate triangle class. I use a razor after printing for minor cleanup. You can laminate the frames after printing for repeated use.

comments.text: Thanks for sharing both these objects and lesson handouts for them. I mentioned your work in my "Teaching with 3D Printing" group (http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/teaching-with-3d-printing) because it's important to have great lesson ideas and plans for teaching with objects.

This repository contains parts to mount a sliding door on a rail.

When I was renovating my house, I had to remove the sliding doors. The existing sliding door was hanging too low for the new carpet and underlay (it's a few mm thicker) and the existing bracket did not have the range of adjustment to suit the thicker carpet. Understandably, after 20 or so years, the rubber wheels were perished too. I looked at what was available in New Zealand and not only were the replacements pretty expensive, they wouldn't really suit the poor installation of the existing doors.

The rails in my house are mounted too high into the wall and it's not possible to simply remove the door by unhooking it and lifting it off. The design of the included part allows you to install the wheel bracket separately from the door, and then attach them. This process is difficult but I'm not sure if there is an alternative, and it does work.

For latest parts and more details visit https://github.com/ioquatix/hanging-door-roller

This is a remix of Ben Wittbrodt's great scan of the husky statue at Michigan Technological University, which can be found here:

title: Knurled Tri-Spinner EDC Fidget Widget / Triple Bearing Spinner

description.text:
Available fully assembled from our Etsy here: http://etsy.me/2fmYlSD

Bearings we use: Amazon, $5.92 for 8

Hatchbox ABS Filament we use: Amazon, ~$20-25 for 1 Kg

EDIT 12/5/16: The Peg Cap has been replaced with a new version that should work a little better! If it doesn't work, try resizing slightly on the X/Y axis depending on your printer!

Our second fidget spinner! These are a ton of fun to play with, and we definitely intend to release several more models as we iterate on this design. We made the design in OpenSCAD, so the original parametric model can be easily modified.

This version of the Tri-Spinner has knurling all around the sides to make it a little easier to grip with one hand.

This spinner has a peg cap, which allows you to to grip the spinner with a pinch grip, and also spin it like a top! We didn't see a similar design yet, so it seemed like a cool addition!

Just print it out and add four 608 bearings; one for the center spinner, and three for added mass around the sides!

description.text: This is an Amazon Kindle 2 docking cradle I designed because I could not find one available anywhere. Step 2. Insert USB cable.
Step 3. Dock Kindle 2. Enjoy!

title: Y-axis Endstop for Prusa i3 Rework

description.text:
This is a rework of a Y-axis endstop. It looks like the one I had was based off this endstop (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:82631). I needed a spacing of 30 mm for my printer so I redrew the part in Fusion 360. I left the slot as a through hole to allow placement on the left or right side of the printer.

Note: Part will most likely need to be rotated 90 deg. about X axis is your printing software. For some reason projects designed in Fusion 360 on the TOP plane are 90 degs out when I load them into the printing software.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3 Rework

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed with MatterControl 1.5 Basic settings with above resolution and infill.
Printed with $5 filament's Rainforest Green Adv. Ingeo PLA

author: Mrbriggs

description.text:
This is a duplicate of the stock effector plate that comes with the kit. I had found some designs that were close, and even supposedly from the company, but none of them matched this one, and they were all off a little bit. This one is made from measurements taken directly from the aluminum plate.
My plan is to use this to design a better e3d v6 dual mount. My current one was temporarily abandonded due to time constraints and researching different solutions. So this one will hopefully be a start toward being able to customize the main plate to allow for adding the e3d heads in more easily.
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001
Basic steering wheel design

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:305087

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=305087

Using the following options:

letter_choice_4 = e
letter_choice_3 = v
letter_choice_2 = i
letter_choice_1 = f
The extruder will use less pulling torque to pull the filament.

I like the fpv racer 190, but thought it was limiting on what you can equip it with. It was made to fit a defined set of gear limiting what you can use. I also found some of the small features to be problematic for some fdm printers. I wanted to have a bit more flexibility on what equipment can be used. 
I have made space for slightly larger motors in the arms. The mounting holes have been reworked to allow for a wider range of motors. I also wanted ample space for gear in the body, it is 5mm taller. 
Access to the usb was limited to only the one side and gave a weak point. I put less intrusive holes on both sides and made the internal cross braces a little bigger. To open up for more pdb options the wall around the xt60 was made thicker.

title: Cactus Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The 'Cactus Stand' is a modular system for hanging up keys, bracelets, watches and more. The stand is made up of a base, which has a tray to hold things like coins etc., then layers with arms protruding to hang things on.

Print in your choice of color/s so it looks like a cactus or alternatively is seen as a modern modular expandable stand for hanging things. Print one for yourself but also great as a gift.

The arms slot onto the layer below and are free to rotate almost 360 degrees... this lets you hang things in a position where they won't interfere with whatever is hanging on the layer below. There are four layer options:

Narrow - Has a 20mm space between the trunk and upright at the end of the arm/s There is a single arm and double arm option.

Wide - Has a 30mm space between the trunk and upright at the end of the arm/s There is a single arm and double arm option.

Two additional files are provided. There is a cap to top the Cactus Stand off and an extension in case you need additional height between layers and arms.

The result is a modular system for hanging all sorts of things. Just print the number of layers / arms to suit what you want to store... and add more later if you want to expand the stand.

With a well sliced file and printed on an accurate / precise machine the layers / arms should rotate smoothly and securely on the layer below. Juts slot one layer onto the pin protruding up from the layer below... it's easy!

Please refer to the images and print instructions provided for additional information... and please post images of your Cactus Stands in use to give others ideas.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my practical and fun designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

PLA / 2 Shells / 25% infill

Notes:

The walls have been designed for strength but the arms and trunk are largely hollow. Using 25% or more infill is however recommended to ensure the arms will hold the weight of heavier things you may want to hang.

Assembly is quick and easy...

Just slot the parts together as shown in the images and hang up your keys, watches, bracelets and more....

You can rotate the arms / layers to help things hang with free space below... and print more arms / layers later to expand it's storage capacity.

comments.text: Pleased you like the design.... and to respond to your query there is no need to change any file/s. The two colored version was printed from the files uploaded. All you need to do is watch your print until the bas tray has finished and your machine has started printing the trunk... then pause your machine and do a filament change  (to a different color) then resume. This will provide a better, stronger and more stable result.

description.text: This is a trumpet stand for setting your instrument on when not in use. It holds a trumpet fairly solidly, and can store inside the bell of the horn for transport.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Support material should be used for all three parts. You'll need to print 5 legs, ideally printed on the flat side for the best strength. The stand cone and screw should be printed upright. All three printed reliably with the Inland PLA I used, though ABS could also be used. I highly recommend a pair of angle-nosed pliers to remove the support material from the inside of the stand cone threads once printed--without them removing the support material will be difficult or even impossible.

A word of warning: the screw piece will put your retraction settings to the test in a big way. Make sure you have them dialed in well before you attempt to print it.

1. Remove supports

Removing supports from the screw piece and stand cone can be quite challenging. I used a pair of forceps and a pair of angle-nosed pliers, along with an exacto knife for cleanup. The hardest parts were the interior of the screw, for which the angle-nosed pliers were nearly required, and the support material beneath the hinge posts. Using a small-bladed screwdriver and a light hammer to tap the support material loose helped, followed by using the forceps to extract any remaining support material.

2. Snap the legs onto the screw

Snap the hook part of each of the legs onto a hinge pin. Push on the bottom of the C of the hinge to make sure it's solidly seated, then rotate the leg downwards. If you encounter any significant resistance, don't force it down--make sure the hinge is properly seated first, try to snap the hinge together more firmly, and check for any obstructions. The most likely time for the hinge to fail is when you first try to extend the leg. The hook on the leg is a bit wider at the bottom to increase structural strength when the leg is deployed, but this can cause a few different types of cracks or breakage if the hinge isn't fully seated.

3. Protect the bell of your horn

Put some adhesive-backed foam or rubber on the base of the cone to protect your bell from scratches--three large pieces arranged around the base seemed to do the trick for me. I would also recommend a band of electrical tape around the top of the cone to prevent the top of the cone from scratching the inside of your bell when placing the horn on or removing it from the stand, as well as when stored in the horn. You don't want anything too thick there or the horn won't fit well onto the cone, but one or two layers of electrical tape at the end of the cone should fit easily, and the rubbery texture will prevent any scrapes or scratches on the horn.
